A lot of twists and deaths. I feel like:
Flashy visually stunning action packed sequel to The Force Awakens. that refreshingly is mostly it's own thing\,
But it horribly fails in basic story telling\, with blatant plot holes\, gimmicky plot-twists\, off-kilter pacing\, lack of character developments and too many characters and plot-lines. It's so bloated\, it never does any of them justice; lingering too long where pacing should have been picked up and rushing where dramatic pauses would have been warranted.
They all comes together in an explosive climax that sizzles out of existence without a cliffhanger or a set-up that makes you want to see the next installment as TESB or TFA did. It feels like an ending\, not a second act!

It also disregarding the trilogies it supposed to add to as well as disregarding most of the set-ups of The Force Awakens\, which painfully lays bear a visionary clash that result in awkwardly clear inconsistencies.
It feels as if there is no overall vision for the entire new trilogy to guide the writer(s). No clue what they want for E-IX\, but also no sneak peaks at the end of TLJ to make us\, viewers curious enough to want to see E-IX
